summary: This document is an attachment to a petition for an advisory opinion regarding a trust agreement. It details the creation of an irrevocable trust by the petitioner (the Senior) and outlines the Senior's substitution power to acquire or reacquire trust property, along with tax implications and procedural requirements.

persons.name: Senior
persons.context: The individual who created the irrevocable trust and holds the substitution power to acquire or reacquire trust property.

keyFacts: An irrevocable trust was created by the Senior, who is deemed to own the trust property for Federal and New York State income tax purposes.
The Senior holds a substitution power allowing them to acquire or reacquire any portion of the trust fund by substituting other property of equivalent value.
The substitution power can be exercised without the consent of the Trustees, but Trustees may seek a court determination if they doubt the equivalent value of substituted property.
The Senior may release the substitution power, and such release must be irrevocable, in writing, signed by the Settlor, and delivered to each Trustee.
New York sales tax was paid by the Senior with respect to property substituted into the trust.
